analytic.title: Moral Decision-making, Empathy, Personal Distress, Resilience and Action and Outcome Aversion of Medical Professionals Performing Invasive Procedures 1 Moral Decision-making, Empathy, Personal Distress, Resilience and Action and Outcome Aversion of Medical Professionals Performing Invasive Procedures

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

abstract.p: (2023.364.IRB3.157). All materials, data, and analysis are available on the OSF, https://osf.io/sp65q/?view_only=c068cf83c7cb44f7997931a93d13b0ae.

div.p: Invasive procedures involve causing harmful actions to benefit patients--often saving their lives (Hoogendoorn & Rodríguez, 2023). In this regard, even though patients consent to invasive procedures, such performance of aversive actions in surgeries psychologically parallel sacrificial moral dilemmas like the famous 'trolley' problem where causing aversive harmful Moral Decision-making, Empathy, Personal Distress, Resilience and Action and Outcome Aversion of Medical Professionals Performing Invasive Procedures 4 actions saves lives (e.g., Foot, 1967;Greene et al., 2001). Such decisions reflect a complex combination of psychological mechanisms, including aversion to causing harmful actions and witnessing harmful outcomes, empathy for victims, personal distress at causing harm, resilience, and aversion to harmful actions and outcomes (Conway, 2023). Drawing on theories of moral decision-making, we anticipated that performing invasive procedures (versus not) would influence individual dispositions in emotional processing and regulation; that physicians who perform invasive procedures and surgeries score lower on empathic concern, personal distress, and action and outcome aversion, and higher on resilience. We moreover predicted these factors would result in 'more utilitarian' sacrificial dilemma decisions among medical professionals performing invasive procedures, due to both reduced rejection of sacrificial harm and increased concern for outcomes as assessed via process dissociation (Conway & Gawronski, 2013). We tested these possibilities in a sample of practicing physicians.

div.head: The Emotion Processing and Stress Resilience of Physicians Performing Invasive
Procedures and Surgery
div.p: Invasive medical procedures entail piercing or penetrating the body of another person for medical purposes that changes the integrity of the body and often causes post-operative pain and/or changes function of the body (e.g., restriction of mobility after amputation). Whereas some medical procedures are minimally invasive (e.g., endoscopy, drug injections), others that are strongly invasive require physicians to perform more aversive actions (e.g., open heart surgery, amputation) ( Thakur Singh et al., 2017). People typically find performing harmful actions physically aversive, independent of the outcomes they achieve Miller et al., 2014). Performing invasive surgery can negatively impact physician well being (e.g., burnout and depression), perhaps in part due to managing emotional demands (Barron & Moral Decision-making, Empathy, Personal Distress, Resilience and Action and Outcome Aversion of Medical Professionals Performing Invasive Procedures 5 Moon, 2022;Smeds et al., 2020). Accordingly, empathy levels among surgeons typically decrease over medical training (Han & Pappas, 2018).

Research documents some individual differences predictive of successful coping with emotional stressors in medical settings (Babore et al., 2020) which may be higher among those performing invasive procedures. For example, Cheng and colleagues (2007) demonstrated that expert acupuncture physicians (vs. control physicians) down-regulate brain regions associated with pain when viewing needles pierce patients. Experts also reported lower empathic pain intensity and unpleasant feelings than non-experts, though dispositional empathy scores were similar. Furthermore, physicians did not experience vicarious empathy as measured by early event-related potentials (ERPs), while viewing images of needles inserted into different body parts; suggesting that learning to perform invasive procedures allows for early regulation of emotions that dampens negative arousals to pain of others (Decety et al., 2010). Other work also finds dispositional differences depending on medical specialty: for example, procedure-oriented specialists (e.g., surgery, anesthesiology and pathology) scored lower on empathy than patientoriented specialties (e.g., primary care specialties, obstetrics and gynecology, and psychiatry, Hojat et al., 2002). Nevertheless, such differences may arise partly from the experience of performing invasive surgery, and partly from self-selection--one paper found that vicarious empathy during medical education predicted selecting non-surgical specialties (Hojat et al., 2020).

Physicians specializing in invasive procedures may also be more resilient--adapt well to difficulties-than other specialists (Feldman, 2020). For example, surgical residents scored higher on resiliency than other residents (Nituica et al., 2021), and students aiming for surgical specialties were more resilient than those who prefer non-surgical specialties (Brügge et al., Moral Decision-making, Empathy, Personal Distress, Resilience and Action and Outcome Aversion of Medical Professionals Performing Invasive Procedures 6 2024). Resilience predicts faster recovery from stressors, lower vulnerability to psycho-social adversity, and better mental health (Russo et al., 2012;Levine et al., 2009). In medical settings, resilience is negatively associated with depersonalization and emotional exhaustion (Lebares et al., 2018). Resilience also is an important protective factor for physicians who are at risk of vicarious traumatization, especially those performing aversive actions during invasive procedures (Arnold-Forster, 2020). Therefore, invasive medical procedures may cause greater personal distress than non-invasive procedures due to the need to cause harm for well-being of patient, leading physicians who are more resilient and better at down-regulating aversive responses to select and flourish in such specialties; regular exposure to invasive procedures may also lead physicians to downregulate such concerns more. If so, then surgeons and physicians performing invasive procedures will less likely to reject harm, but more likely maximize outcomes, in sacrificial dilemmas, as well as demonstrate related patterns for empathic concern, personal distress, resilience, and action and outcome aversion.

div.head: Sacrificial Moral Dilemmas
div.p: Sacrificial moral dilemmas typically entail deciding whether to cause harm that maximizes outcomes, such as the well-known 'trolley problem' where pulling a lever can redirect a runaway trolley to kill one person and save five lives (Thomson, 1986). Causing harm is said to violate deontological ethics that judge the morality of an action by its nature (i.e., harm is wrong, Kant, 1959), but uphold utilitarian ethics that judge an action by the outcomes it produces (i.e., saving people is right, Mill 1861/1998). Notably, medical ethics emphasize both deontological prohibitions--'first, do no harm'--and utilitarian ideals--such as triage to save the most people (Mandal, et al., 2016). Nonetheless, medical ethics often emphasize a utilitarian approach of maximizing patient and public wellbeing even if doing so requires invasive Moral Decision-making, Empathy, Personal Distress, Resilience and Action and Outcome Aversion of Medical Professionals Performing Invasive Procedures 7 intervention, especially under emergency conditions (Vearrier & Henderson, 2021).

Accordingly, people often expect utilitarian decisions from leaders and professionals such as scientists, which may extend to medical professionals (Uhlmann et al., 2013;Sosa & Rios, 2019). After all, invasive treatments like surgery to increase patient wellbeing (and prevent the spread of disease to the community) parallel the logic of sacrificial dilemmas and may therefore involve similar psychological mechanisms.

Researchers have documented a complex array of psychological mechanisms that contribute to decisions in sacrificial dilemmas (Conway, 2023). The simplest model is a 'dual process' model whereby affect-laden intuitive aversion to causing harm motivates rejection of sacrificial harm, whereas cognitive deliberation regarding overall outcomes motivates harm acceptance (to maximize outcomes, Greene et al., 2001). Indeed, there is support for this general affective-cognitive distinction. For example, individual differences related to affective reactions to harm predict rejecting sacrificial harm in sacrificial dilemmas, such as empathic concern (Gleichgerrcht & Young, 2013), anxiety and personal distress (Sarlo et al., 2014), and 'mirror neuron' activation when witnessing harm (Christov-Moore, et al., 2017), whereas measures related to cognitive processing typically predict acceptance of sacrificial harm (e.g., Patil, et al., 2021). That said, researchers have documented important roles for many other processes, such as concerns about following rules, general action aversion, and strategic self-presentation (e.g., Piazza & Landy, 2013;Gawronski et al., 2017;Rom & Conway, 2018) and re-imagined processes as neural systems (Cushman, 2013;Crockett, 2013). Hence, the dual process model is far from complete, but may describe two of many processes contributing to dilemma judgments. toward 'more utilitarian' (or 'less deontological') responding (e.g., Druică et al., 2023); others find no difference, or even that medical (vs. non-medical) students are less willing to endorse utilitarian judgments (or more willing to endorse deontological judgments) when they benefit as part of the majority (Park, et al., 2024 with affective aversion to harm--empathic concern, moral identity, aversion to both causing and witnessing harm, and lower psychopathy, whereas the utilitarian parameter was uniquely related to measures related to moral concern of overall outcomes--e.g., cognitive processing, moral identity, and sometimes also lower psychopathy (Conway et al., 2018a;Reynolds & Conway, 2018;Byrd & Conway, 2019;Patil et al., 2021). That said, findings reveal far more complexity than a simplistic dual process view; for example, general prevention mindsets increase deontological responding, and cognitive reflection appears to increase deontological responding among some religious people (McPhetres, et al., 2018;Gamez-Djokic & Molden, 2017).

Furthermore, the utilitarian parameter partly reflects concern for outcomes with general action tendencies (Gawronski, et al., 2017), and the parameters can be subdivided even further (Skovgaard-Olsen & Klauer, 2024). Nonetheless, most studies suggest an association between the deontological parameter and affective concerns regarding harm, and utilitarian parameter and concerns about overall wellbeing (Conway, 2023).

Moral Decision-making, Empathy, Personal Distress, Resilience and Action and Outcome Aversion of Medical Professionals Performing Invasive Procedures 10 Importantly, process dissociation can detect suppression--cases where people score high (or low) on both parameters simultaneously, which then cancel out in conventional judgments that treat them as opposites. For example, people high in moral identity score high on both

parameters, suggesting strong concerns about both rejecting sacrificial harm and maximizing outcomes--whereas people high in psychopathy score low on both parameters, suggesting weak concerns about rejecting harm and maximizing outcomes (e.g., Conway & Gawronski, 2013;Conway et al., 2018a;Maranges et al., 2021). Either way, such patterns largely or completely cancel out for conventional dilemma judgments, depending on the relative strength of each effect. Likewise, experimentally inducing distrust increased both parameters, again resulting in null effects on conventional dilemmas, even though participants in the distrust condition reported feeling more torn between responses (Conway et al., 2018b). As process dissociation is sensitive to cases of suppression invisible to conventional dilemma judgment, it allows for detecting whether physicians performing invasive procedures reject sacrificial harm less and maximize outcomes more, or some other pattern.

div.head: Aversion to Causing and Witnessing Harm
div.p: Sacrificial dilemmas parallel invasive procedures insofar as they entail performing harmful actions for laudable reasons. Many people consider invasive procedures as aversive, and surgical pictures are often used to assess aversive arousal (Yang et al., 2020). However, physicians must inhibit aversive arousals to distressful actions and outcomes to perform successful procedures (Haque & Waytz, 2012). Similarly, action aversion theory suggests that emotional responses to sensory-motor representation of harmful action itself causes harm rejection independent from negative outcomes. For example, performing typical harmful actions, "pointing a rubber knife at friend's throat," in a pretend play elicits stronger physiological Moral Decision-making, Empathy, Personal Distress, Resilience and Action and Outcome Aversion of Medical Professionals Performing Invasive Procedures 11 arousals than witnessing the same action performed by others, and performing metabolically equivalent harmless action "cutting a bread" . On the other hand, outcome aversion theory suggests that other-oriented concern for harm, such as empathic concern for victims, causes harm rejection responses. Consistent with the findings that surgeons score lower on a variety of measures related to distress over harm, such as stress immunity and physician empathy (Pegrum & Pearce, 2015;Hojat et al., 2002), they may likewise tend to score lower on both action and outcome aversion.

To test this possibility, we assessed action and outcome aversion via the self-report scale developed by Miller and colleagues (2014). Whereas Miller and colleagues (2014) found that action aversion predicted rejection of sacrificial harm better than outcome aversion, Reynolds and Conway (2018) clarified this pattern via process dissociation: they found that action aversion predicted lower deontological and higher utilitarian responding, whereas outcome aversion predicted higher deontological and utilitarian responding (suppression). We anticipated replicating this pattern, and that different moral judgments between physicians performing invasive procedures and surgeries (versus not) would partly reflect lower action and outcome aversion of the former versus latter groups--as physicians regularly performing invasive procedures and surgeries should regulate aversive responses to harmful actions itself for greater concern of future suffering of patients. Likewise, we predicted that physicians regularly performing invasive procedures should score lower on empathy and personal distress than their colleagues.

div.head: The Current Work
div.p: In this study, we anticipated that medical professionals performing invasive procedures (versus not) would make 'more utilitarian' sacrificial judgments because they score lower in Moral Decision-making, Empathy, Personal Distress, Resilience and Action and Outcome Aversion of Medical Professionals Performing Invasive Procedures 12 harm rejection (deontological parameter) and higher in outcome maximization (utilitarian parameter). We also grouped physicians with respect to their area of specialization; surgical vs.

non-surgical (see Supplement). We likewise predicted a similar pattern emerged for those reporting surgical versus non-surgical specialities (unregistered). We furthermore predicted that physicians regularly performing invasive procedures (versus not--preregistered) and reporting surgical (versus other--unregistered) specialties would score lower on empathic concern, personal distress, higher on resilience and lower on action and outcome aversion.

We further predicted that action and outcome aversion, empathetic concern, and personal distress, would be positively associated and resilience negatively associated with deontological tendencies, whereas outcome aversion and resilience would be positively associated with utilitarian tendencies. Therefore, we anticipated that each of these variables would mediate (i.e., carry significant indirect variance) between group membership and each process dissociation parameter (preregistered for invasive procedures versus not, unregistered for surgeon versus not).

To test these predictions, we recruited practicing medical professionals, who reported whether they frequently perform invasive procedures like surgery. We grouped physicians with respect to their area of specialization; surgical vs. non-surgical (see Supplementary material).

They completed a battery of 10 sacrificial moral dilemmas, each with two variants, allowing for computation of two independent parameters that separately measure harm aversion (deontological parameter) and outcome maximization (utilitarian parameter) via process dissociation (Conway & Gawronski, 2013). They also completed measures of action and outcome aversion, empathic concern and personal distress, and resilience as listed in the

div.head: Transparency and Openness
div.p: We preregistered predictions via AsPredicted: https://aspredicted.org/y83t-rdfm.pdf. We reported hypotheses, all measures, analysis, data exclusions, sample size and exploratory variables. We received ethical approval from [details blinded for review] (2023.364.IRB3.157).
We analyzed data via SPSS (version 28.0.0). All materials, data, and analysis are available on the OSF, https://osf.io/sp65q/?view_only=c068cf83c7cb44f7997931a93d13b0ae .

div.head: Method Participants
div.p: As pre-registered, we originally aimed to recruit 500-600 physicians. Our invitation reached 918 physicians across Turkey via emails sent by Turkish Medical Chambers and physician WhatsApp groups, with 685 proceeding to consent. For quality purposes, we excluded participants who did not consent (n=54), were not physicians (n=22, missing=28), failed to complete >94% of study, i.e., all sacrificial dilemmas (n=252), otherwise failed to answer all dilemmas (n=22), failed an attention check (n= 80, missing=3), or did not answer each dilemma between 5-180 sec (n=93). After exclusions, the final sample size was 131. 2

div.head: Translation Strategy
div.p: We translated sacrificial moral dilemmas and action/outcome aversion into Turkish in four steps. First, two researchers independently translated all moral dilemmas and Moral Decision-making, Empathy, Personal Distress, Resilience and Action and Outcome Aversion of Medical Professionals Performing Invasive Procedures 14 action/outcome items from English to Turkish. Then, the researchers and the supervisor professor proofread two of the Turkish versions and agreed on a common Turkish translation.

The agreed version was translated back into English with ChatGPT (OpenAI, 2024) to assess whether the Turkish translation was consistent with the original English version. Finally, researchers discussed any discrepancies between original dilemmas and English translated versions of Turkish dilemmas and modified them accordingly.

div.head: Procedure and Materials
div.p: Participation was voluntary and participants provided consent and completed all measures online via Qualtrics. After informed consent, participants answered demographic and work-related questions, individual differences scales (empathic concern, personal distress, resilience and, action and outcome aversion) sacrificial moral dilemmas, and some exploratory measures to assess depression and professional quality of life. 3

div.head: Demographics
div.p: Participants reported their area of specialization, age, sex, and religiosity. For exploratory purposes, they also reported the number of working years, frequency of invasive techniques applied in the last month, number of invasive procedures in the last year, number of deceased patients witnessed in the last month, disease severity of patients cared for in the last month, academic education, and the type of hospital that worked at.

div.head: Empathic Concern and Personal Distress
div.p: Participants completed the 7-item empathic concern and personal distress subscales of the Interpersonal Reactivity Index (IRI); where perspective-taking or fantasizing were not assessed.
Moral Decision-making, Empathy, Personal Distress, Resilience and Action and Outcome Aversion of Medical Professionals Performing Invasive Procedures 15

Developed by Davis (1983) and validated by Duru (2002) into Turkish, the IRI assesses empathic concern, the degree to which one experiences warmth, compassion, and concern for others (Sometimes I don't feel very sorry for other people when they are having problems, α = .69), and personal distress, unease and discomfort felt in response to the feelings of others (When I see someone who badly needs help in an emergency, I go to pieces, α= .75) on scales from 1 (does not describe me well) to 5 (describes me very well).

div.head: Connor-Davidson Resilience Scale (CD-RISC)
div.p: Participants completed a 25-item resilience scale by indicating how true statements (e.g.,
Can handle unpleasant feelings) were over the past month on a 5-point scale (0: not true at all to 4: true nearly all the time). The scale, developed by Connor and Davidson (2003) and validated

into Turkish by Karaırmak (2010), assesses various aspects of resilience, some of which measure individual characteristics such as considering change and stress as challenges, adaptability under pressure, focus and thinking clearly, tolerance of negative affect, and action-oriented approach to coping. We calculated the cronbach alpha of the scale as α = .89 .

div.head: Action and Outcome Aversion
div.p: We assessed five items of action and outcome scale of Miller and colleagues (2014).

Action aversion items represent aversion to performing prototypically harmful actions without negative outcomes (e.g., Stab a fellow actor in the neck during a play using a stage knife with a retractable blade). Outcome aversion items represent aversion to witnessing other's suffering one did not cause (e.g., See a chef cut their finger by accident). Participants reported how upset they would be to perform each action and witness the painful outcome on 7-point scales (1 = Not at all, 7 = Very much). 4 We computed the mean of action (α = .69) and outcome (α = .84) which increased reliability to α = .73. As results held either way, we ultimately retained all items.

div.head: Process Dissociation Dilemma Battery
div.p: Participants responded to 10 sacrificial moral dilemmas, each with two versions, describing situations where harmful actions cause particular outcomes, which allows for a process dissociation analysis (Conway & Gawronski, 2013). For each harmful action, participants selected either Yes, this is appropriate or No, this is not appropriate (see Greene et al., 2001). Incongruent dilemmas describe harmful actions that lead to greater overall outcomes, consistent with utilitarian ethics but violating deontological ethics, such as killing a baby to save a village from death. Congruent versions of each dilemma describe the same harmful act, but the positivity of outcomes has been reduced such that harm arguably no longer maximizes outcomes, so harm violates both deontological and utilitarian ethics, such as killing a baby to save a village from hard labor. Each dilemma appeared on a single page in a fixed-random order. Following the six process dissociation equations described by Conway and Gawronski, we computed the proportion of times people accepted and rejected harm for each dilemma type, and then used linear algebra to solve for a) the tendency to reject harm regardless of outcomes (deontology parameter) and b) maximize outcomes regardless of causing harm (utilitarian parameter--see Appendix for calculations).

div.head: Statistical Analysis
div.p: We computed descriptive statistics for demographics, type of procedures regularly performed, area of speciality, age, sex, religion, and other work-related exploratory variables.
We computed mean scores for individual differences scales and tested reliability via Cronbach's (Hayes, 2017).

div.head: Participants
div.p: We We conducted a 2 (between-subjects: regularly performing versus not performing invasive procedures) ✕ 2 (within-subjects: utilitarian and deontological parameters) mixed ANOVA (see Figure 1). Contrary to expectations, this analysis revealed no significant main effect of parameter, F(1,129) =.35 , p=.576 , ηp 2 = .00 , nor interaction, F(1,129) =2.45 , p=.120, ηp 2 = .02. Moreover, the main effect of performing invasive procedures was not significant as well, F(1,129) =2.81, p=.074, ηp 2 = .03 (see Figure 1). Therefore, physicians regularly performing invasive procedures (M= -.07 , SD= 1.06) did not differ from those not performing invasive procedures in overall score across the deontological and utilitarian parameters (M= .15 ,

div.head: SD=.83 ). 5
div.p: We conducted a parallel (unregistered) analysis comparing physicians who reported specializing in surgery to those reporting other specialties. This 2 ✕ 2 ANOVA revealed no significant main effect of parameter, F(1,129)=.42, p=.518, ηp2 =.00, or interaction, F(1,129) = We also compared physicians who regularly perform invasive procedures (versus not) on deontological score, utilitarian score, personal distress, empathic concern, resilience, and action and outcome aversion. Inconsistent with predictions, no individual differences reached significance. However, we found that surgeons scored significantly lower in the deontology parameter but not in the utilitarian parameter. (see Table 1). We likewise compared surgeons to non-surgeon specialists with the PD scores and the same personal differences variables (see Table 1). Consistent with our theorizing, surgical practitioners scored significantly higher in resilience and lower in deontological parameter and personal distress than non-surgeons, although there were no significant group differences on utilitarian parameter, action or outcome aversion or empathic concern. 7

div.head: Correlational, Regression, and Mediation Analyses
div.p: We preregistered expectations that the deontological parameter would be associated with higher empathic concern and personal distress, lower resilience, and higher action and outcome aversion, whereas the utilitarian parameter would be associated with higher scores on outcome aversion and resilience. We first assessed correlations (see Table 2; see Supplement for correlations between exploratory variables). Largely inconsistent with expectations, the deontological parameter did not correlate significantly with any measure except (as predicted)

lower resilience, and the utilitarian parameter was unrelated to any measure. Consistent with past work, the deontological and utilitarian parameters were uncorrelated with one another, but correlated in opposite directions with conventional 'utilitarian' dilemma judgments. Finally, correlations were moderate to strong, rs = .23-.58, between empathic concern, personal distress, action aversion, and outcome aversion--with the exception of resilience, which was not significantly correlated with any of these measures except lower personal distress. Next, we regressed the utilitarian and deontological parameters on predictors to clarify the unique variance explained by each predictor controlling for relationships between them, though we did not register this analysis per se. 8 We separately regressed each dependent variable on empathic concern, personal distress, resilience, action and outcome aversion, and whether physicians regularly perform invasive procedures (dummy coded Yes=1, No=0, see Table 3).

Overall model fit was significant for the deontology, F(9,121)= 2.53 , p=.011 , though not utilitarian parameter F(9,121)=1. 04 , p=.417 , 9 We found that participants who tended to reject Moral Decision-making, Empathy, Personal Distress, Resilience and Action and Outcome Aversion of Medical Professionals Performing Invasive Procedures 23 sacrificial harm (deontology parameter) scored lower in resilience and personal distress and higher in outcome aversion, and were less likely to perform invasive procedures. 10

div.head: Table 3
div.p: Regressions

div.head: Discussion
div.p: This study compared physicians who routinely perform invasive procedures (versus do not) and specialize in surgery (versus other specializations) in terms of their decisions in sacrificial moral dilemmas and their scores on empathy and personal distress, resilience, and action and outcome aversion. We anticipated that physicians who routinely engage in aversive actions during their duties would make 'more utilitarian' or 'fewer deontological' sacrificial decisions due to both reduced harm rejection and increased outcome maximization. Even though harm rejection and outcome maximization tendencies were not differ across physicians who perform invasive procedures and those who not, results partly corroborated predictions: surgeons (versus other specialities ) indeed showed lower concern for rejecting sacrificial harm in dilemmas (i.e., lower deontology parameter scores)--but also lower concern for maximizing overall outcomes (i.e., lower utilitarian parameter scores (though this simple effect was not significant, so we interpret this finding with caution). Hence, physicians who engage in more aversive medical procedures like surgeries appear more willing to accept sacrificial harm, but not more focused on outcomes--if anything they may be less focused on outcomes than other physicians who do not perform surgeries. This pattern parallels the pattern for other groups relatively insensitive to harm, such as those high in dark traits (e.g., Conway et al., 2018a;Maranges et al., 2021) or in a mindset where they generally trust their moral intuitions (Conway, et al., 2018b). It may be that such insensitivity to harm is useful or pragmatic for physicians who regularly perform aversive actions in surgeries.

That said, inconsistent with expectations, physicians who routinely perform invasive procedures did not score higher on harm acceptance and higher on outcome maximization, as well as lower on empathy or personal distress, higher on resilience, or lower on action and Moral Decision-making, Empathy, Personal Distress, Resilience and Action and Outcome Aversion of Medical Professionals Performing Invasive Procedures 25 outcome aversion. It may be that we lacked statistical power to reliably detect such effects, or it may be that physicians differ from one another less than anticipated. On the other hand, although non-surgeon groups also reported performing invasive procedures, these interventions may not be as extensive as those performed by surgeons in terms of affecting organ function and may involve lower levels of risk. Nonetheless, consistent with expectations, we did find that surgeons scored lower in harm rejection and outcome maximization; also lower in personal distress and higher in resilience than physicians specializing in non-surgical areas (though neither mediated the impact of physician group membership on dilemma responding). This pattern is similar to past work showing that surgeons scored higher in resilience and lower in physician empathy than physicians who specialized in non-surgical practices (Nituica et al., 2021;Hojat et al., 2002), though these measures differ somethat from the measures in the current work. Hence, results tentatively offer some, albeit mixed, evidence consistent with our theory that physicians who regularly deal with invasive procedures like surgery are less impacted by concerns about performing aversive actions for greater good.

div.head: Implications for Physicians
div.p: This work extends a growing body of work investigating differences in emotion-related processing between physicians specializing in invasive procedures with other specialties to the domain of sacrificial moral decision-making. Our findings suggest that physicians who regularly perform aversive actions in surgical procedures are less averse to causing sacrificial harm, and potentially also less concerned with outcomes, than their peers. This finding aligns with studies showing that physicians expert on acupuncture down-regulate pain empathy to medical treatments they routinely perform, though their scores on empathic concern were not different than controls (Cheng et al., 2007). Insofar as performing surgeries parallels the psychology of Moral Decision-making, Empathy, Personal Distress, Resilience and Action and Outcome Aversion of Medical Professionals Performing Invasive Procedures 26 sacrificial dilemmas, those regularly doing so appear more comfortable with performing aversive actions that involve harm.

Additionally, our findings showed that surgeons, who may often perform particularly invasive procedures such as open heart surgery, scored higher on resilience and lower on personal distress than other specialists. This pattern is consistent with findings that surgeons tend to score higher on stress immunity (e.g. lack of arousal to stress), fearlessness (e.g. eagerness to take risk, lack of concern or anxiety about harm), and resilience, as well as lower on physician empathy than other physicians, and that resilience and low personal distress predict choosing to specialize in surgery (Pegrum & Pearce, 2015;Nituica et al., 2021;Brügge et al., 2024;Hojat et al., 2020).

Such patterns align with our argument that low sensitivity to aversive and harmful actions may be useful for physicians expected to regularly perform surgical procedures that commonly produce stronger aversive reactions than minimally invasive procedures, like slicing someone open with a scalpel . Consistent with this argument, dehumanization of patients may operate as a coping strategy to reduce the cost of inflicting pain on patients during surgical procedures and viewing their sufferings (Haque & Waytz, 2012). For example, surgeons may dehumanize their patients in the form of moral disengagement to minimize guilt arising from inflicting pain, which then allows for the justification of harm (Hoogendoorn & Rodríguez, 2023;Bandura, 1999). Hence, physicians may wish to consider such psychological aspects of medical care when selecting specialties or hiring staff. That said, physicians should balance such considerations with findings that empathy for patients can improve outcomes (Gleichgerrcht & Decety, 2011). Hence, low sensitivity to harm may be more useful in some medical specialties and less useful in others.
Moral Decision-making, Empathy, Personal Distress, Resilience and Action and Outcome Aversion of Medical Professionals Performing Invasive Procedures 27

div.head: Implications for Dilemma Research
div.p: Results also partially corroborate and partly challenge past research on sacrificial dilemmas. Consistent with most past work, the PD parameters were uncorrelated, and correlated in opposite directions with conventional judgments (e.g., Friesdorf et al., 2015;cf. Kunnari et al., 2020). Unlike in past work (Reynolds & Conway, 2018), outcome aversion did not predict increased deontological responding with a similar pattern of increased utilitarian responding that was not significant. Similarly, action aversion did not predict either reduced utilitarian responding and increased deontological responding, but negatively predicted utilitarian vs.

deontological judgements. Surprisingly, we did not replicate past work that found empathic concern predicted deontological responding (e.g., Conway & Gawronski, 2013). It is difficult to know why findings were different; one possibility is that medical professionals as a group show a somewhat different profile of empathy and aversion than previous participants, who were largely students or online workers. Another possibility is that these patterns reflect different cultural experiences in moral decision-making (e.g., Awad, et al., 2020). It may also be that we simply lacked the statistical power to cleanly detect effects, considering that power to detect correlations stabilizes around 250 participants (Schönbrodt & Perugini, 2013).

However, we obtained the expected and novel finding that deontological responding is associated with reduced resilience. This finding fits our theory that people who regularly perform invasive surgery appear less concerned about sacrificial harm and higher in resilience, suggesting an ability to 'bounce back' from the emotional impact of performing aversive actions that changes integrity of the body (even though patients are under anesthesia) and cause postoperative pain due to functional changes of body. This finding meshes with research on the moral dilemma decision-making of paramedics and fire service incident commanders (vs.

Moral Decision-making, Empathy, Personal Distress, Resilience and Action and Outcome Aversion of Medical Professionals Performing Invasive Procedures 28 controls), who are especially skilled at controlling their negative arousal towards moral conflict in dilemmas (Francis et al., 2018). Results suggest that more trained helping professionals had lower emotional arousal, measured by heart rate variability, when exposed to distressful dilemmas during VR, even though their dilemma responses were not different to controls.

Notably, this work employed only conventional dilemmas; the current work suggests that professionals may score lower on both deontological and utilitarian responding--a pattern of suppression only detectable via process dissociation--which would explain the reduced reactivity (e.g., see Conway & Reynolds, 2018;Conway, et al., 2018b;Maranges et al., 2021). Notably, resilience was not associated with outcome-maximizing (utilitarian) responding, consistent with arguments that such responses tend to reflect more cognitive considerations (e.g., Byrd & Conway, 2019;Patil et al., 2021).

div.head: Limitations and Future Directions
div.p: The current work has several limitations. First, this study employed self-report measures, with famous limitations related to inaccuracy in self-perception, self-presentation, and memory (Paulhus & Vazire, 2007). Therefore, future work may supplement self-reports of action and outcome aversion with physiological measures such as skin conductance response and heart rate variability (HRV) to assess autonomic nervous system activity of physicians with different specialties towards moral conflict Park et al., 2016), and supplement selfreport dilemma judgements with decisions in virtual reality (Francis et al., 2018). Similarly, responses to hypothetical dilemmas may differ from decisions in real-life (e.g., Körner et al., 2019), though hypothetical dilemmas may nonetheless remain useful for assessing the psychological processes underlying morality (Cushman & Greene, 2012), which may parallel the mechanisms involved in surgical procedures where aversive actions must be performed. Even Specializing in surgery may be attractive to people relatively immune to the distress of performing aversive actions (Miller et al., 2014), or surgeons may simply become accustomed or desensitized to actions that cause harm over time (Bandura, 1999). It may also be that instrumental learning to perform aversive actions in a goal-directed manner during medical procedures may desensitize vicarious reactions of physicians to harm or increases resilience toward distress, which may manifest themselves in personal dispositions as lower personal distress and higher resiliency. The current results are compatible with either mechanism; future studies are needed to determine whether harm rejection in dilemmas decreases with regular exposure to aversive actions in real life. Nor can our results speak to general differences between people who practice medicine versus those who do not, as all participants were physicians.

We preregistered analyses to assess harm aversion and outcome maximization tendencies of physicians performing invasive vs. non-invasive procedures. However, this analysis did not reveal any significant main effect in dilemma responding, and also no individual difference variables were significant. Therefore, we considered an alternate operationalization of the construct: surgeon versus other specialization. The pattern of dilemma decision-making for this group partly confirmed the preregistered analysis, though only for surgeon classification:

physicians specialized in surgery scored lower on sacrificial harm rejection (deontology Moral Decision-making, Empathy, Personal Distress, Resilience and Action and Outcome Aversion of Medical Professionals Performing Invasive Procedures 30 parameter) and outcome maximization (utilitarian parameter) than other specialists. Moreover, dispositional differences in resilience and personal distress emerged only for surgical vs. nonsurgical specialty groups, rather than the broader category of regularly performing invasive procedures versus not. Surgery may involve more harmful and viscerally aversive actions than typical invasive procedures, such as the slicing and bone-sawing involved in open-heart surgery versus the modest stab of a standard needle injection. Hence, surgery may entail stronger aversive harm cues and hence more utility from low sensitivity to performing stronger aversive harmful actions in surgeries than mere invasive procedures. That said, we couldn't obtain a similar pattern of dilemma responding for both groups, but we did find physicians engaging in surgical procedures reject harm and maximize outcomes less, such that they also score higher on resilience and lower on personal distress than physicians who work in specialization other than surgery. Future work may profit from clarifying the strength of aversive reactions of physicians across specialities to different types of invasive procedures; this may help physicians detect difficult procedures and learn how to control aversive responses inherent to aversive actions in medical procedures. Even though our findings did not replicate the comment that the moral decision-making patterns of surgeons are similar to those of individuals with high trait psychopathy which are characterised by reduced vicarious empathy to pain, aversion to harm and increased in eagerness to take risks which are critical for moral dilemma resolutions, trait psychopathy can be a measure that should be taken into account in future studies. (Alshukri et al., 2024;Glen et al., 2009;Nituica et al., 2021). That said, trait psychopathy may be another personality variable important to deal with aversive responses during surgeries that can be measured in future studies.

div.head: Conclusion
div.p: Moral Decision-making, Empathy, Personal Distress, Resilience and Action and Outcome Aversion of Medical Professionals Performing Invasive Procedures 31

Performing invasive procedures in a medical setting may require overcoming aversion to harmful actions, so reduced concerns about performing aversive action that causes bodily harm may be useful to such physicians. Partly consistent with this view, surgeons (but not physicians performing invasive procedures) were less likely to reject sacrificial harm and maximize overall outcomes than other physicians, and they also tend to score higher on resilience and lower on personal distress. Such patterns may reflect the utility of reduced emotional distress for physicians who must regularly perform aversive actions during their medical duties.

versa--cannot effectively test these questions because each 'utilitarian' response on conventional
dilemmas could reflect strong concern about outcomes, weak concerns about rejecting harm, or
some other combination. Process dissociation (PD, Conway & Gawronski, 2013), one of a
family of models for teasing apart response tendencies underlying dilemma responses (e.g., see
Gawronski et al., 2017), entails recording responses to both incongruent dilemmas where causing

figure.figDesc: Moral Decision-making, Empathy, Personal Distress, Resilience and Action and Outcome Aversion of Medical Professionals Performing Invasive Procedures 29 though performing a surgery is not a dilemma for the physician, our results imply that this experience or choice of surgery also affects physician's decisions on moral dilemmas. These findings suggest that people who work other jobs requiring performance of aversive harmful actions for greater good, such as butchery or veterinary medicine, may likewise demonstrate reduced sensitivity to such aversive actions that cause harm and perhaps also maximizing outcomes.

body.note: These inventories will be described in a separate publication. 2 Exclusion rates were higher than anticipated, perhaps because our targeted population is very busy(Asch et al., 2000) and our study was long, resulting in dropout(Thorpe et al., 2009). A sensitivity analysis in G*Power suggested that 131 participants can detect a medium effect of Cohen's d=.44 with 80% power at α = .05 in a 2✕2 mixed ANOVA design(Faul et al., 2007).

For exploratory purposes, we also included additional two self-report measures, "The Patient Health Questionnaire-9 (PHQ-9)" and "Professional Quality of Life Scale-IV (ProQOL R-IV)"(Kroenke et al., 2001;Stamm, 2005). The first scale assesses depressive symptoms, while the other assesses the positive and negative impact of helping with three scales; compassion satisfaction, burnout and compassion fatigue.
The word "upset" in the question sentence was adapted to Turkish as "disturbing".

Exploratory analyses revealed that none of the main effects significant after controlling for age and sex, and when controlling for demographic variables: religiosity, years of work, invasive procedures performed in the last year and last month, number of patient deaths encountered in the last month, education, and of hospital type,6 We again re-ran exploratory analyses controlling for the same sets of confounds. The main effect of surgical specialty remained significant controlling for age and sex F(1,127) = 4.84 , p=.030 , ηp 2 = .04; however effects did not held when controlling for all demographic variables, F(1,127) = 3.26 , p=.073 , ηp 2 = .03 .
We anticipated a similar pattern for all measures for surgeon versus nonsurgeons as with invasive versus noninvasive procedures, though we did not preregister these analyses.

However, we preregistered mediation analyses similar to these predictions. 9 When replacing the dummy code for invasive vs. not with surgery vs. other specialty, patterns remain similar with the overall model for the deontological parameter, F(9,121)=2.54 , p=.010 .

Exploratory analysis showed that regression results remain similar without controlling for age and sex; when additionally controlling for all demographic variables, overall fit was not significant for either the deontological, F(8,122)=.70 , p=.691, or utilitarian parameter, F(8,122)=.85, p=.563 .

div.head: Appendix: Process Dissociation Calculations
div.p: Calculating the deontology and utilitarian PD parameters involves recording participants' decisions to accept versus reject sacrificial harm across both congruent and incongruent dilemmas. Harmful action maximizes outcomes for incongruent, but not congruent, dilemmas.

Thus, responses consistent with utilitarianism entail accepting harm on incongruent dilemmas but rejecting harm on congruent dilemmas; responses consistent with deontology entail consistently rejecting harm.
Consider the processing tree in Figure A1 The probability of rejecting harm on incongruent dilemmas is represented as:
The probability of accepting harm on incongruent dilemmas is represented as:
Rearranging these four equations allows for algebraically solving for the two unknown variables, U and D, as follows:
Then plugging in this value of U allows for computing D:

Together, these six equations allow for converting acceptability responses to congruent and incongruent dilemmas into independent estimates of the degree to which responses align with utilitarian concerns (maximizing outcomes regardless of causing harm) and deontological concerns (rejecting harm regardless of outcomes).
